topics.title: Visualization to reduce public speaking anxiety
topics.summary: Matt explains visualization as a desensitization tool: mentally rehearse arriving, speaking, audience reactions, and leaving the stage. He notes research support and mentions VR tools that simulate different audience behaviors.

topics.title: Dare to be dull: connection over perfection
topics.summary: They discuss reducing self-judgment by aiming for connection rather than flawless performance. Matt frames it as an improv-inspired mindset that frees cognitive bandwidth and often improves results.

topics.title: Reframe nerves as excitement
topics.summary: Matt shares cognitive reframing research: anxiety and excitement feel similar physiologically, but labeling the arousal as excitement can improve performance and perceived communication quality.

topics.title: Mantras and managing negative self-talk
topics.summary: They cover using short mantras (e.g., "I have value to add," "It’s not about me") to counter internal criticism. Matt also discusses personifying the inner critic and normalizing anxiety as common.

topics.title: Distract and convert presenting into conversation
topics.summary: Matt describes tactics to get through the most anxious moments (right before and first minute of speaking), such as starting with a question, video, or facilitated discussion to shift from presenting to conversing.

topics.title: Breathing techniques and embodied cognition
topics.summary: They discuss how body state influences mind state, and Matt explains breathing methods emphasizing longer exhales (rule of lung) to trigger relaxation and improve voice control.

topics.title: Tongue twisters, warmups, and strategic swearing
topics.summary: Matt shares presence-building warmups like tongue twisters to focus attention and warm the voice, including a live example. He also mentions research that swearing can blunt anxiety (with caveats about context).

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Coda (and earlier: Sprig and Dovetail) describing product offerings and promotional links/credits.

topics.title: Why spontaneous speaking matters and is learnable
topics.summary: They transition to on-the-spot speaking: Matt argues most speaking is spontaneous, that anyone can improve, and that you must "prepare to be spontaneous" through practice and mindset work.

topics.title: Using structure to think and speak clearly
topics.summary: Matt explains why lists fail under pressure and how simple structures reduce cognitive load by separating "what to say" from "how to say it." They introduce common frameworks like problem-solution-benefit.

topics.title: Practical frameworks: PREP and What-So what-Now what
topics.summary: They discuss specific structures for product/work contexts: PREP (Point, Reason, Example, Point) and What/So what/Now what for updates, features, and recommendations.

topics.title: Remembering structures: practice, reflection, feedback
topics.summary: Matt advises naming frameworks with mnemonics and building reps by summarizing content using the structures and analyzing others’ communication. He emphasizes improvement requires repetition, reflection, and feedback.

topics.title: Where to practice: Toastmasters and improv
topics.summary: Matt recommends Toastmasters for structured repetition and improv for presence and collaboration (not comedy). He positions both as accessible ways to practice spontaneous speaking skills.
